## SEASON &amp; CROP REPORT TAMILNADU

2023-2024

Fasli Year:1433

Department of Economics and Statistics Chennai-600 006

## Preface

Agriculture  in  TamilNadu  plays  a  crucial  role  in  the state's economy, contributing significantly to the production of various crops. The state is known for cultivating staples such as  rice,  pulses,  and  millets,  sustaining  a  diverse  agricultural industry.  TamilNadu is endowed with several rivers, including the  Cauvery,  and  widespread  irrigation  networks,  ensuring adequate water supply for farming activities.

Tamil Nadu encompasses a cultivable expanse spanning 79.32 lakh hectares, with a net cultivated area of approximately 47.56 lakh hectares. The annual production  of food grains for the year 2023-24 reached 109.51 lakh tonnes.

To  fulfill  the  information  requirements  of  stakeholders, the Department of Economics and Statistics (DES) in the state annually releases the "Season and Crop Report of TamilNadu ." This report is a vital repository of data concerning  key  parameters  in  the  primary  sectors  of  the economy. The insights gleaned from the report play a pivotal role in shaping  government  policies related to food and agriculture. The data presented in this publication specifically relates to the year 2023-24  and  has  been meticulously gathered and compiled from the Village 'G' Return.

The  Average  Yield  Rates  for  principal  crops  have  been computed based on the output obtained from Crop Estimation

Surveys, which were conducted with the assistance of officials from the Department of Agriculture and Horticulture. Furthermore,  the  Department  of  Economics  and  Statistics independently  conducts  Crop  Estimation  Surveys,  deploying Statistical  Inspectors  as  field  staff.  These  surveys  cover  8 Fruits and 5 Vegetable Crops, Coconut and Arecanut crops, as well  as  Minor  Crops  like  Chillies,  Onion,  Turmeric,  Tapioca, Potato, Ginger, Coriander, and Cashewnut.

This report offers a comprehensive overview of the price landscape, encompassing Wholesale Prices, Retail Prices, and Agricultural wages. The data for these aspects were meticulously  collected  by  the  Department  of  Economics  and Statistics.

The report is structured into three major parts:

Part-I: This  section  provides  a  textual  presentation  covering the behavior of the monsoon, Land Use Pattern, Irrigation, and a comparative analysis of the Area, Production, and Yield rate of Principal Crops in comparison to the previous year (2022-23).

Part-II: This part provides Summary  tables and Index Numbers related to the Agricultural Economy.

Part  -  III: This  part  presents  district-wise  data  on  Rainfall, Land  use  Statistics,  Sources  of  Irrigation,  Area,  Production,

Yield Rate of Crops, Agricultural Wages, Wholesale and Retail Prices, among other factors.

Additionally, an effort has been made to visually represent the past five year's data on the Area and Production of  Principal  crops  in  Tamil  Nadu.  This  visualization  aims  to provide a clear understanding of the production trends in the region.

It is anticipated that the data provided in this report will prove  beneficial  to  all  stakeholders  in  the  effective  planning and implementation of agricultural programmes for the sustainable development of the Agricultural sector in the State.

The  dedicated  work  of  the  officials involved in the preparation of this publication is appreciated. Suggestions for further improvement are welcomed and encouraged.

Place: Chennai -6

Date: 31.01.2025

S.Ganesh, I.A.S., Commissioner of Statistics

The pivotal role of agriculture continues to dominate the economy of the State. Agriculture remains the primary  source  of  livelihood in TamilNadu, sustaining the majority of rural households. More than two-thirds of these households rely on agriculture, with approximately 93 percent classified as small and marginal farmers. The agricultural sector has significantly contributed to alleviating rural poverty in the  state  over  the  years.  In recognition of its crucial role, the state has introduced various  initiatives aimed  at enhancing the growth and performance of Agriculture.

## Executive Summary

TamilNadu is situated in the southern part of India, bordered by the States of Karnataka and Kerala to the west,  Andhra  Pradesh  to  the north, and the Bay of Bengal to the east. Its southern boundary  is  defined  by  the Indian Ocean. The State's geographical location has endowed it with diverse landscapes and features with a  geographical  area  of  130 lakh  ha.  and  is  the  Tenth largest State in India.

The fertile plains of the Cauvery River basin dominate  the  central  part  of the State, supporting extensive agricultural activities. TamilNadu experiences a tropical climate,  characterized  by  hot and dry weather for a significant  part  of  the  year, with the monsoon season bringing rainfall from October to December.

of TamilNadu  occupies 4%  of India's total geographical area  but  possesses  only  3% of water resources. The State has  a  coastal  line  of  1076 kms. It  is  the  second  largest Economy and the most urbanised State in the country.

The Eastern Ghats run along the western edge TamilNadu, influencing its topography with hills and plateaus. The Western Ghats also  have  an  impact  on  the State's geography,  with  the Nilgiri  Hills,  Anaimalai  Hills, and Palani Hills contributing to its scenic beauty.

## 1.Rainfall and Seasonal Conditions

The  sub-agro-climatic  zone of TamilNadu  is  primarily influenced by Bi-monsoon patterns,  which  dictate  the rainfall in the region. Due to its  location  on  the  eastern side of the Western Ghats, a significant portion of TamilNadu experiences a notable deficit in reliable rainfall during  the  SouthWest monsoon.

All districts, except Chengalpattu, Kallakuruchi, Ramanathapuram,  Tenkasi, Thirunelveli, Thoothukudi, and Kanyakumari, experienced  higher  rainfall compared to the normal rainfall of their respective districts.

The actual rainfall  recorded during  the  year  is  1117.9 mm, while the normal rainfall  is  965.6  mm.  This represents a decrease of 4.50%  when  compared  to 2022-23. The North-East monsoon contributed 44.3% of  the  annual  rainfall,  and the South-West monsoon contributed 33.5% during the year 2023-24.

The Chennai district received  the  highest  rainfall at  1950.9  mm,  followed  by Tirunelveli district with 1855.3 mm. Karur recorded the  lowest  rainfall  at  555.8 mm.

The season-wise contribution of rainfall to the total recorded during 2023-24  is  detailed  below, providing  insights  into  the distribution  and  impact  of rainfall throughout the year.

## 2.Agro Climatic Regions of TamilNadu

Tamil Nadu State is categorized into seven distinct  agro-climatic  zones based  on  factors  such  as rainfall distribution, irrigation  pattern,  cropping pattern, soil characteristics, and other physical, ecological, and social attributes. The  delineation of these zones is as follows:

(excluding hilly areas), Salem, Namakkal District (excluding Tiruchengode Taluk), and Krishnagiri districts.

## (i) North Eastern Zone:

This  zone  encompasses  the districts of Chennai, Kancheepuram, Vellore, Chengalpattu, Tirupathur, Tiruvallur, Cuddalore (excluding Chidambaram and Kattumannarkoil Taluks), Tiruvannamalai, Ranipet, and Villuppuram.

(ii) North  Western  Zone: This zone includes Dharmapuri district

(iii) Western Zone: Comprising Erode and Coimbatore districts, Tiruchengode Taluk of Namakkal district, Karur Taluk of Karur district, Dindigul (excluding Dindigul and Natham Taluks), Perambalur, Theni, Ariyalur, and Tiruppur districts.

## (iv) Cauvery Delta Zone:

Encompassing  the  Cauvery Delta area in Thanjavur, Nagapattinam,

Tiruchirapalli, and Tiruvarur districts, Kulithalai Taluk of Karur district, Aranthangi Taluk of

## 5. Distribution of land in various districts

## Forest

The Forest category encompasses all areas classified or administered as Forest under any legal enactment,  whether  owned by the state or privately owned. Erode district stands out with a substantial extent of 2,27,511 hectares under Forest, marking the highest contribution among districts to the  State's  total  Forest area.  This  figure  represents 11%  of  the  State's  overall Forest area. A distinctive characteristic of The Nilgiris district is that approximately  56%  of  the total  area  in  the  district  is covered by forests.

## Barren and Unculturable Land

Land that is difficult or costly to cultivate, including areas like mountains, deserts, and hills, is classified as barren and uncultivable land. Salem district stands out, contributing 38,198 hectares, which accounts for  8.4%  of  the  State's  total barren and uncultivable land. This category encompasses  approximately 3.5%  of  the  State's  entire geographical area.

## Land put to Non Agricultural Uses

The category of land designated for purposes other than agriculture includes  areas  utilized  for buildings,  pathways,  roads, social forests, bus-stands, railway tracks, canals, rivers, local reservoirs, swamps, marshy and waterlogged  areas,  as  well as  land  under  still  water, among others.

Given its status as the capital city, approximately 81.5% of Chennai's geographical area is dedicated to nonagricultural uses, with Kancheepuram district following closely at 38.5%.

## Culturable Waste

Land available for cultivation  but  not  utilized for at least one year and not cultivated during the current year or continuously for the last five years  or  more  is  classified as  Culturable  Waste.  These lands  may  either  lie  fallow or  be  covered  with  shrubs and  jungles  not  utilized  for any  purpose.  Karur  district alone contributes 18.6% (65,085 hectares) of the total area of the state under this category.

## Permanent Pastures and other Grazing Lands

All  grazing  lands,  including permanent pastures and meadows, fall under this category. Village common and grazing lands within the Forest area are also included. Chengalpet district has the highest extent  under  this  category in the state, covering 13,396 hectares (12.5%).

## Misc. Tree Crops  and Groves not included in the Net Area Sown

This category includes all cultivable lands not classified under Net area sown  but  used  for  various agricultural  purposes,  such as  lands  under  Casuarina, Eucalyptus,  Teak,  Bamboo bushes, Babul, Thatching grass,  and  other  groves  for fuel. These lands, which bear yield only once in their

entire  lifespan  and  are  not included under orchards, fall under this classification. Thoothukudi  district  ranks first in this category, contributing 20,604 hectares, accounting for 12.1%  of  the  total  area  in the State. Pudukkottai district  follows  with  14,743 hectares (8.6%).

## Current Fallow Lands

Lands  left  fallow  from  the Net  area  sown  during  the previous year are categorized as Current Fallow for the reporting year.  Tiruvanamalai  district leads  in  this  category  with 94,241 hectares (9.8%), followed by Tiruppur (76,049 hectares)and Villupuram (72,529 hectares)  districts  at  7.9% and 7.5%, respectively.

## Other Fallow Lands

Other Fallow Lands include areas  temporarily  taken  up for cultivation but temporarily  set  aside  for  a period  of  not  less  than  one year but not more than five years due to factors such as poverty among  cultivators, insufficient water supply, silting  of  canals  and  rivers, etc. Virudhunagar district reports the highest land under this category with 1,68,256 hectares (9.0%), followed by Sivagangai district with 1,30,829 hectares (7.0%).

## Net Area Sown

The Net Area Sown represents the land cultivated under the first crop  during  the  Fasli  year. In  the  year  2023-24,  out  of the  total  geographical  area, 47,56,135 hectares,

constituting 36.5%, were cultivated once with various crops. This reflects a decrease of 81,664 hectares (1.7%) compared to the previous year (2022-23), which  recorded  an  area  of 48,37,799 hectares. Tiruvannamalai district contributes 4.9% to the state's Net Area Sown. When comparing the Net Area Sown with the geographical area of the district, Tiruvarur district takes  the  lead  with  74.6%, followed  by  Mayiladuthurai district with 62.7%.

## Gross Area Sown

The Gross Area Sown represents the total area cultivated under all Food and Non-Food crops, including  areas  sown  more than  once  during  the  Fasli year. In 2023-24, the Gross Area  Sown  is  reported  at 61,16,616 hectares, exhibiting a decrease of 1,43,903 hectares (2.3%) from the 62,60,519 hectares recorded in 2022-23.

## Area Sown  more  than once

The  Area  Sown  more  than once represents the difference between the Gross  Area  Sown  under  all crops and the Net Area Sown during the Fasli year. In 2023-24, this area is reported at 13,60,481 hectares, showing a decrease  of  4.4%  compared to 14,22,720 hectares in 2022-23. The Area Sown more  than once accounts for 22.2% of the Gross Area Sown  in  the  State  during 2023-24. Tiruvarur,

Thanjavur,  Tiruvannamalai, and Cuddalore districts contribute significantly to this category.

## Cropping  Intensity

Cropping  intensity  is defined as the ratio between the  Gross  Area  Sown  and the Net Area Sown. In Tamil Nadu, the Cropping Intensity for the year 2023-24 is 1.29. Mayiladuthurai district records the highest Cropping  Intensity  at  2.27, followed by Tiruvarur district with 1.92. This metric provides insights into the level of agricultural activity and  the  extent  to which cultivable land is utilized for multiple  crops within a given period.

## Canals (Including System Tanks)

Canals play a crucial role in providing irrigation in TamilNadu. The irrigation system's tanks receive water from permanent storage facilities  such  as  reservoirs and dams. The land irrigated by this water source is categorized as being served by canals. During 2023 24, -Canal irrigation accounted for 20.91% of the net area irrigated  by  all  sources  in the  State. Canals  are  the only  source  of  irrigation  in Mayiladuthurai and Tiruvarur Districts, and hence 100% of net area irrigated  is  through  Canals, which is followed by Nagapattinam  district  with 97.7%. Delta districts of Thanjavur, Tiruvarur,

Mayiladuthurai and Nagapatinam together share about  74%  of  the  total  net area  irrigated  by  canals  in the State.

## Tanks  (Non-System  Tanks Only)

Non-system tanks rely entirely  on  rainfall,  as  they are  supplied  both  by  their independent catchment areas  and  the  diversion  of river water and jungle streams. The Non-system tanks contribute about 13.9% of the net area irrigated  by  all  sources  in Tamil Nadu during the year 2023-24. Tanks are the main source of irrigation  in respect of Ramanathapuram district,  where  82.1%  of  its total area irrigated was only from tanks which is followed by Sivagangai with 71.3%.

## Wells

In  Tamil  Nadu,  wells serve as the primary source of irrigation. During the year 2023-24, open wells and  tube-wells  /  bore-wells continued to be the principal source of irrigation. The net area irrigated    by   open   wells and tube-wells/bore-wells together  accounted  for  19.8 lakhs  ha.  (about  62.8%  of the  total  Net  area  irrigated) in 2023-24.

The net area irrigated by wells during the year 2023-24 was highest in Tiruvannamalai district with 1.78 lakh ha. With the exception of certain delta districts, nearly all other districts  in  TamilNadu  rely on  wells  as  their  primary irrigation source.  In  these districts, wells contribute to over  45.2%  of  the  total  net irrigated area.

## Gross Area Irrigated

In the year 2023 24, -the Gross  Area  Irrigated,  which comprises the net area

irrigated and the area irrigated more  than once, accounted  for  to  38.3  lakh hectares. This reflects a decrease from 38.6 lakh hectares recorded in 2022-23, marking a decline of 0.8%.

## Intensity:

Irrigation  intensity,  defined as  the  ratio  of  gross  area irrigated to net area irrigated, is a key metric indicating  the  efficiency  of irrigation  practices.  In  the state of Tamil Nadu, the Irrigation  Intensity  for  the year 2023 24 -is 1.33. Certain districts, such as Dharmapuri (1.85), Tiruvallur (1.71), Mayiladuthurai (1.70), Thiruvarur (1.69), Thanjavur (1.61) and The  Nilgiris (1.58), exhibit significantly  high  irrigation intensity ratios. These figures underscore the effectiveness of irrigation practices in these regions.

The  Food  Grain  Production serves as a crucial indicator of the Agricultural Economy.  In  Tamil  Nadu, the  total  area  dedicated  to food grains accounts for 30.54  lakh  hectares  out  of the gross 61.17 lakh hectares. In the year 2023 24, there was a 2.65% -decrease in area and 6.33% decrease in production of Food Grains compared  to the previous year.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

Paddy cultivation alone encompasses 21.02 lakh hectares,  constituting  56% of the total area under food grains. Paddy holds a substantial share of 68.81% among all cereals. Both Cholam and Maize contribute 14.89% and 11.61%,  respectively  to  the overall  cereals.  Of  the  total food grain production of 109.51 lakh tonnes, Cereals and Millets contribute 105.64 lakh tonnes, accounting for nearly 96.47%. Within cereals, Rice  takes  the  lead  with  a share  of 64.36%,  followed by Maize with a 25.90% share  of the total cereals production.

<!-- image -->

<!-- image -->

The area contributed to pulses  accounts  for  12%  of the Gross Area sown. Specifically,  the  area  under pulses  is  reported  at  7.17 lakh hectares, with Black gram contributing significantly at 3.55 lakh hectares, constituting nearly half of the total pulses area. There has been a 9.37% decrease in the area under pulses, while the production has seen an decrease  of 23.3%.

The overall production of pulses  stands  at  3.86  lakh tonnes, making up approximately  3.53%  of  the total  food  grain  production. In comparison to the previous year, the production of Black gram has decreased by 33.1%, and Greengram has witnessed a decrease of 29.82%.

Total Foodgrains encompass Cereals,  Millets,  and  Pulses collectively. In addition to the principal crops cultivated in Tamil Nadu, certain crops grown in limited quantities within the state  are  categorized  under Other Cereals and Other Pulses. Other Cereals include Kudiraivali, Panivaragu, and Wheat, while Other Pulses comprise

Mochai,  Avarai, KalPayiru, NariPayiru, Peas, and Beans.  The  contribution  of 'Other Cereals' is 9347, tonnes,  and  'Other  Pulses' contribute  35990  tonnes  to the total Foodgrain Production in TamilNadu. The  graph  below  illustrates the  area  and  production  of Foodgrains over the past five years.

## 10. Five Years trend of Principal Crops

## 1.Paddy

Paddy stands as the predominant  crop  extensively grown across nearly all districts  within  the  state.  The cultivation of Paddy in the region follows a distinctive three season pattern, comprising Kar/Kuruvai/ Sornavari (April-July), Samba/ Thaladi/Pishanam (Aug-Nov), and Navarai/Kodai (Dec-Mar). In the agricultural landscape of  the  state  during  2023 24, -Paddy  claimed  a  substantial share, amounting to 34.36% of the  total  gross  cropped  area. Notably, Tiruvarur district emerged as the leader, with an extensive area of 2.24 lakh hectares, followed by Thanjavur  district with 2.10 lakh hectares and Tiruvannamalai with 1.85 lakh hectares.

## 5. Other Millets / Cereals

In  addition  to  Paddy,  Jowar, Bajra,  and  Ragi,  Tamil  Nadu cultivates  a  variety  of  other cereals, including Maize, Korra (Thinai), Varagu, Samai, Kudiraivali, Panivaragu, and Wheat.

Maize covers an extensive area  of  4.55  lakh  hectares, spanning most parts of Tamil Nadu, excluding the Delta districts of Tiruvarur, Nagapattinam, Mayiladuthurai, and the districts of Ranipet, Tiruvallur, Kancheepuram, Sivagangai, Kanniyakumari, Nilgiris, and Chengalpattu. Maize  holds  the  position  of the second-largest contributor to the state's food grain production, yielding nearly 28.36 lakh tonnes, which accounts for 26.84% of the total food grains production. Among millets, Samai boasts the largest cultivated area, covering 14,628 hectares, predominantly grown in Tiruvannamalai,

Dharmapuri, Vellore, and Tirupathur districts. Following closely is Kudiraivali,  with  an  area  of 5,776  hectares,  cultivated  in Virudhunagar,  Madurai,  and Ramanathapuram districts of Tamil Nadu.
